journal-title-group.journal-title: American journal on intellectual and developmental disabilities

title-group.article-title: The Role of Executive Function in Independent Living Skills in Female Adolescents and Young Adults With Fragile X Syndrome

contrib.aff: Center for Interdisciplinary Brain Sciences Research (CIBSR), Stanford University
Educational and Counseling Psychology Department, McGill University
Center for Interdisciplinary Brain Sciences Research (CIBSR), Stanford University
Center for Interdisciplinary Brain Sciences Research (CIBSR), Stanford University

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence concerning this article should be addressed to Allan L. Reiss, Center for Interdisciplinary Brain Sciences Research (CIBSR), Stanford University, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, 401 Quarry Road, Stanford CA 94305 USA (areiss1@stanford.edu)

abstract.p: Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is associated with executive function (EF) and independent living skills (ILS) deficits. We examined the role of childhood EF in ILS during adolescence/early adulthood in females with FXS and two comparison groups in the same age range (matched for IQ [IQ/Age group] and with another genetic condition, Turner syndrome [TS group]). EF and ILS were significantly higher for the FXS group than the IQ/Age group but did not differ from the TS group. For the FXS group, age and EF were significant predictors of ILS during adolescence/early adulthood, but there were no statistically significant longitudinal associations between EF and ILS. Our findings suggest that impairments in EF may have a significant effect on ILS in FXS.
